titlestmt.author: Compiled by Curtis Nelson and Adrienne Nesnow

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:04

did.abstract: Correspondence, music, and photographs by and about the American music librarian, critic, music administrator, recording executive, and program annotator Leonard Burkat (1919-1992)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Leonard Burkat Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Burkat in 1979.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Leonard Burkat Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 25, The Leonard Burkat Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In four series as follows: I. Correspondence. II. Music. III. Photographs. IV. Original Register.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Leonard Burkat Papers consist primarily of correspondence written to Burkat by composers, conductors, musical performers, and writers. The Papers also contain manuscript corrections from Lukas Foss regarding his Oboe concerto and from William Walton regarding his Cello concerto. Photographs are also included in the Papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Leonard Burkat was born in Boston, Massachusetts on July 20 or 21, 1919. As a boy, he attended the Boston Latin School and played saxophone and oboe. Later he took courses at Boston University, Harvard University, and the Columbia University School of Library Science. Burkat had several careers in music. He wrote music criticism for the Boston Globe and the Boston Evening Transcript. He worked as a music librarian at the Boston Public Library, and then, beginning in 1946, for the Berkshire Music Center and the Boston Symphony Orchestra; eventually he became the Orchestra's artistic administrator. In 1963, Burkat joined Columbia Records; by the time of his retirement in 1973, he was a vice-president. In his later years, he established the Leonard Burkat Program Note Service; he wrote program notes for thousands of works, and they were used by hundreds of prominent orchestras and soloists. Leonard Burkat died in Danbury, Connecticut on August 25, 1992.

odd.head: General
odd.p: For additional correspondence from Lukas Foss and William Walton, see Series II.

odd.head: General
odd.p: 2 autograph letters signed from Felicia Bernstein

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1 card signed from Olivier Foss, Lukas' brother

odd.head: General
odd.p: 2 typed letters signed, one in Russian, the other an English translation

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1 copy of poems from Day of Love

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1 Typescript of section of interview by Janet Baker-Carr of Burkat entitled "Leadership in the Arts: A Study on the Relocation of Authority"

odd.head: General
odd.p: Also includes letters from Lukas Foss and William Walton concerning music in this series.

did.unittitle: [Die Natali] Die Natali; chorale preludes for Christmas, op. 37, c1960.

odd.head: General
odd.p: On title page: Commissioned in celebration of the 75th season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, Music Director. Dedicated to the memory of Serge and Natalie Koussevitzky. Phrasing by Charles Munch. Complete holograph at the Library of Congress.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Rehearsal notes in the composer's hand (4 leaves. 22 x 14 cm.) for premiere (3/8/57) laid in.

did.unittitle: [Concerto, oboe] Concerto for oboe and orchestra.
Autograph letters signed, 1951 Jan., no day, Rome, to Burkat.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Relates to changes and corrections to be made in his oboe concerto for its premiere with Ralph Gomberg and the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Charles Munch. This letter was enclosed with the copy of the score listed above.

did.unittitle: [Concerto, violoncello] Concerto for violoncello and orchestra.
Autograph letters signed, 1956 Nov. 27, Forio d'Ischia, Italy, to Charles Munch.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Relates to changes and corrections to be made in the 3rd movement of his 'cello concerto. This letter was enclosed with a copy of the score listed above

odd.head: General
odd.p: Except for one photograph of Leonard Bernstein and his family in 1972, all of the photographs in this series were taken at a dinner party at Leonard Burkat's home in Brookline, Massachusetts on November 13, 1959.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes autobiographical essay by Burkat (4 p.), advertisement for his program note service (2 p.), and Burkat's comments (14 p.) on the letters he had received and their authors.
